title-group.article-title: Effects of Recombinant Dentin Sialoprotein in Dental Pulp Cells

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Maxillofacial Tissue Regeneration, School of Dentistry and Institute of Oral Biology, Kyung Hee University, 1 Heogi-dong, Dongdaemun-gu, Seoul, 130-701, Republic of Korea
2Department of Conservative Dentistry, School of Dentistry, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
3Department of Biochemistry, Inha University School of Medicine, Incheon, Republic of Korea

fn.p: individuals contributing equally to this work as first authors

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 International & American Associations for Dental Research
permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: Dentin sialophosphoprotein (DSPP) is critical for dentin mineralization. However, the function of dentin sialoprotein (DSP), the cleaved product of DSPP, remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the signal transduction pathways and effects of recombinant human DSP (rh-DSP) on proliferation, migration, and odontoblastic differentiation in human dental pulp cells (HDPCs). The exogenous addition of rh-DSP enhanced the proliferation and migration of HDPCs in dose- and time-dependent manners. rh-DSP markedly increased ALP activity, calcium nodule formation, and levels of odontoblastic marker mRNA. rh-DSP increased BMP-2 expression and Smad1/5/8 phosphorylation, which was blocked by the BMP antagonist, noggin. Furthermore, rh-DSP phosphorylated extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK), Akt, and IκB-α, and induced the nuclear translocation of the NF-κB p65 subunit. Analysis of these data demonstrates a novel signaling function of rh-DSP for the promotion of growth, migration, and differentiation in HDPCS via the BMP/Smad, JNK, ERK, MAPK, and NF-κB signaling pathways, suggesting that rh-DSP may have therapeutic utility in dentin regeneration or dental pulp tissue engineering.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Human dental pulp cells (HDPCs) have the ability to create reparative dentin when the dental pulp tissue is damaged. This process involves the proliferation, migration, and differentiation of HDPCs into odontoblasts (Magloire et al., 1996). Osteocalcin (OCN), osteopontin (OPN), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), dentin matrix protein-1 (DMP-1), and dentin sialophosphoprotein (DSPP) have been used as mineralization markers for the odontoblast/osteoblast-like differentiation of HDPCs (About et al., 2000; Gronthos et al., 2000). However, the precise mechanism of HDPC conversion into odontoblasts remains unclear.

DSPP is one of the key non-collagenous proteins involved in tooth development and mineralization, and is mainly expressed in odontoblasts (Butler and Ritchie, 1995). Dentin phosphophoryn (DPP) and dentin sialoprotein (DSP) are specific markers for terminally differentiated odontoblasts and are encoded by a single gene, DSPP, located on mouse chromosome 5 and human chromosome 4 (MacDougall et al., 1997). To date, no full-length DSPP protein has been isolated from or identified in dentin. Mutations in DSPP are associated with the inherited genetic disorder dentinogenesis imperfecta types I and II (Zhang et al., 2001). Recently, a single mutation in the DSP signal peptide was found to be responsible for the genetic disorder dentin dysplasia type II (Rajpar et al., 2002). Further, DSPP knock-out mice exhibited the dentinogenesis imperfecta type III phenotype (Sreenath et al., 2003). Recently, the overexpression of DSPP by adenovirus in adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) was found to enhance the expression of odontogenic genes, ALP activity, and the formation of mineralization nodules (Wu et al., 2008). Thus, DSPP is a key molecule in normal dentinogenesis.

DSP, the amino-terminal part of DSPP, is a sialic-acid-rich glycosylated protein. Its function in ontogenesis remains obscure. However, the unique expression of DSP in odontoblasts and predentin just before the onset of mineralization suggests that it may participate in dentin formation (Watanabe and Takano, 2002). DSP has little or no effect on hydroxyapatite (HA) formation or growth, suggesting that its primary role in dentin is not the regulation of mineralization (Boskey et al., 2000). Analysis of in vivo data suggests that DSP may be involved in the initiation of dentin mineralization, but not in the maturation of dentin tissue (Suzuki et al., 2009).

However, to our knowledge, the effect of DSP, and its underlying mechanism, during the differentiation of HDPCs into odontoblasts has not been reported. The aim of this study was to assess the influence of recombinant human DSP (rh-DSP) on the proliferation, migration, and odontoblastic differentiation of HDPCs. Furthermore, the impact of DSP on signaling pathways implicated in odontoblastogenesis was investigated.

sec.title: Cell Culture
sec.p: We used the HDPCs lines immortalized by transfection with the telomerase catalytic subunit hTERT gene (Kitagawa et al., 2007). Cells were cultured in α-MEM supplemented with 10% FBS, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 μg/mL streptomycin in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2 at 37°C. To induce differentiation, we treated cells with osteogenic media (OM, 50 μg/mL ascorbic acid and 10 mM β-glycerophosphate, and 0.1 μM dexamethasone) from days 0 to 14 as previously reported (Wei et al., 2007).

sec.title: Preparation of rh-DSP Protein
sec.p: The cDNA encoding human DSP was amplified with the human DSP cDNA as a template by PCR for 30 cycles with Taq DNA polymerase and the DSP forward primers 5′- CTAGATCTCAATA GAAATCAAGGGTC-3′ and reverse primer 5′- TGGTACCAT TATCCTTGCATGGACTTA-3′. The amplified cDNA product was digested with restriction enzymes BglII and KpnI. After digestion, PCR products were ligated into the multiple cloning sites of pBAD-HisA (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) and transfected into E. coli TOP10 strain. The crude protein from the sonicated bacterial supernatant was purified through binding of the hexahistidine tag to the nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid resin column, according to the manufacturer’s protocol (Invitrogen).

sec.title: Measurements of Endotoxin Activity
sec.p: The endotoxin activities of rh-DSP preparations were determined with the Limulus amoebocycle lysate assay kit (BioWhittaker, Walkersville, MD, USA) according to the manufacturer’s recommendation.

sec.title: MTT Cell Growth Assays
sec.p: Cell proliferation was studied by 3-(4,5-methylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyl-tetrazolium bromide (MTT) assays.

sec.title: Chemotaxis Assay
sec.p: Chemotaxis was assayed with QCM™ chemotaxis 24-well colorimetric cell migration kits (Chemicon, Temecula, CA, USA) following the manufacturer’s instructions.

sec.title: ALP Activity Assay
sec.p: Cells were sonicated with a cell disruptor. ALP activity was measured with p-nitrophenyl phosphate (3 mM final concentration; Sigma, St. Louis, MO, USA) as the substrate in 0.7 M 2-amino-methyl-1-propanol, pH 10.3, and 6.7 mM MgCl2. Absorbance was measured at 410 nm by means of an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay reader (Beckman Coulter, Fullerton, CA, USA).

sec.title: Alizarin Red Staining
sec.p: Treated cells were fixed in 95% methanol for 45 min at 4°C followed by washing with H2O. The cultures were then stained with 2% Alizarin red S (Sigma) for 5 min at room temperature, washed with de-ionized H2O, and observed under a microscope.

sec.title: Semi-quantitative Reverse-transcriptase-Polymerase Chain-reaction (RT-PCR)
sec.p: The total RNA of pulp cells was extracted with the Trizol reagent (Life Technologies, Gaithersburg, MD, USA) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Then, 1 μg RNA was reverse-transcribed for first-strand cDNA synthesis (Gibco BRL, Rockville, MD, USA). The cDNA was amplified in a final volume of 20 µL containing 2.5 mM magnesium dicholoride, 1.25 units Ex Taq polymerase (Bioneer, Daejeon, Korea), and 1 μM specific primers. Amplification was carried out for 30 cycles in a DNA thermal cycler. Primer sequences for differentiation markers were detailed as previously described (Wei et al., 2007; Kim et al., 2010). The PCR products were resolved on a 1.5% agarose gel and stained with ethidium bromide.

sec.title: Western Blot Analysis
sec.p: We prepared total cell extracts by solubilizing cells in SDS-protein lysis buffer for 30 min on ice. The cell lysates were centrifuged at 14,000 × g for 20 min. The cytosolic fractions were extracted by buffer containing 10 mM Tris (pH 8.0), with 1.5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, 0.1% NP-40, and protease inhibitors. Nuclei were separated from cytosol by centrifugation at 12,000 rpm at 4°C for 15 min, and nuclear fractions were extracted from the pellets by buffer containing 10 mM Tris (pH 8.0), with 50 mM KCl, 100 mM NaCl, and protease inhibitors. Equivalent amounts of total protein from each cell extract were separated by electrophoresis in a 12.5% SDS-polyacrylamide gel. After electrophoresis, the proteins were transferred onto a membrane, which was then treated with blocking solution for 1 hr and incubated with primary and horseradish-peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies for 1 hr each at 37°C. The proteins were visualized in an enhanced chemiluminescence system (Amersham, Piscataway, NJ, USA).

sec.title: Immunocytochemistry
sec.p: Briefly, treated cells were fixed with 4 % paraformaldehyde for 30 min following permeabilization with 0.1 % Triton X-100. After being washed in PBS buffer, slides were blocked with 1% normal goat serum for 1 hr and then incubated with mouse monoclonal anti-human p65 antibody (Cat. no. SC8008, Santa Cruz Laboratories, Santa Cruz, CA, USA) for 2 hrs at a 1:100 dilution. The slides were washed with PBS, incubated with fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG (Invitrogen, cat. no. A11001) at a 1:100 dilution for 1 hr, and counterstained for nuclei with 10 μg/mL propidium iodide. Slides were imaged at x400 magnification on a confocal microscope (Leica, Wetzlar, Germany).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Values were calculated as the mean and standard deviation. Statistical significance was evaluated by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with the SPSS (v10.0; SPSS, Chicago, IL, USA) computer program.

sec.title: Expression of Purified rh-DSP
sec.p: The molecular mass of the purified rh-DSP was found to be 12 kDa, as shown by SDS-PAGE and Western blot with the anti-polyhistidine antibody (Fig. 1A). Exogenous rh-DSP significantly increased the expression of DSP protein in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 1B).

caption.p: Expression of purified recombinant human DSP (A), effect of rh-DSP on the expression of DSP protein (B), proliferation (C), and chemotaxis (D) of human dental pulp cells (HDPCs). Eluted rh-DSP was subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotting (A). Proliferation and chemotaxis were determined by MTT and colorimetric cell migration assays, respectively. The expression of DSP was assessed by Western blot analysis. Cells were incubated in osteogenic medium [OM: 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 50 μg/mL L-ascorbic acid, 10 mM β-glycerophosphate, 10−7 M dexamethasone] or osteogenic supplement (OS: 10% FBS, 50 μg/mL L-ascorbic acid, 10 mM β-glycerophosphate). Data are representative of 3 independent experiments. *Statistically significant difference compared with control, p < 0.05; #statistically significant difference compared with OM positive control group, p < 0.05.

sec.title: Effects of rh-DSP on Cell Proliferation and Migration
sec.p: To examine the effects of DSP on HDPC growth and chemotaxis, we conducted MTT and migration assays (Figs. 1C, 1D). rh-DSP promoted HDPC growth and migration in time- and dose-dependent manners.

sec.title: Effects of rh-DSP on Odontogenic Potential
sec.p: To investigate the potential of HDPCs undergoing odontoblast-like differentiation under DSP treatment, we assessed ALP activity (Fig. 2A), alizarin red stain reaction (Fig. 2B), and mRNA levels of differentiation markers (Fig. 2C). ALP activity and calcium nodule formation were markedly stimulated by rh-DSP in dose- and time-dependent manners. The effect of rh-DSP on the mRNA expression of differentiation markers, including ALP, OPN, OCN, DSPP, and DMP-1, was concentration-dependent from 1 to 20 ng/mL. The stimulation of ALP activity, mineralization, and marker gene mRNA expression peaked after 14 days of 10 ng/mL rh-DSP treatment, similar to the effects of treatment with 10 ng/mL rh-BMP-2.

caption.p: Effect of recombinant human dentin sialoprotein (rh-DSP) on human dental pulp cell (HDPC) differentiation. Endotoxin assay in recombinant rh-DSP (D). Effects of polymyxin B on rh-DSP-induced odontoblastic differentiation markers for 14 days (E). Differentiation was determined by alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity (A), mineralization nodule formation by alizarin red staining (B), and mRNA expression by RT-PCR (C). rh-DSP was tested by use of the Limulus lysate endotoxin assay kit (D). Cells were incubated with 20 ng/mL rh-DSP for 48 hrs (D) or 14 days (E) in the presence of 10 μg/mL polymyxin B. ND; not detected (D). Data are representative of 3 independent experiments. *Statistically significant difference compared with control, p < 0.05; #statistically significant difference compared with OM positive control, p < 0.05.

sec.title: Absence of Endotoxin on rh-DSP
sec.p: To confirm the possibility that the observed effect of rh-DSP was due to contaminants present in the rh-DSP preparation, we determined the functional characteristics as well as endotoxin contents. The level of endotoxin contents of the rh-DSP preparations (1 μg) was always found to be below 0.12 EU/ mL by Limulus amoebocyte lysate assay, which was not affected by endotoxin inhibitor polymysin B (10 μg /mL ) (Fig. 2D). In addition, polymyxin B had no effects on rh-DSP-stimulated ALP, OPN, OCN, DSPP, and DMP-1 mRNA expression (Fig. 2E). Analysis of these data demonstrated that endotoxin contamination of the rh-DSP preparation does not appear to be the basis for our observations.

sec.title: Effects of rh-DSP on Signal Transduction Pathways
sec.p: As shown in Fig. 3A, rh-DSP stimulated the phosphorylation of Akt, c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK), and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), but not p38 MAPK, a response which was similar to the effects of treatment with rh-BMP-2. We investigated the effect of rh-DSP on NF-κB activation by measuring I-κBα degradation, I-κBα phosphorylation, and RelA/p65 regulation of NF-κB in HDPCs. Maximum phosphorylation and degradation of I-κBα and maximal expression of p65 were detected after incubation for 60 min in rh-DSP (Fig. 3B). To confirm this finding, we investigated the effect of rh-DSP on the nuclear translocation of NF-κB p65. Increased NF-κB p65 in the nucleus was detected by immunofluorescence 1 hr after rh-DSP treatment (Fig. 3C).

caption.p: Effect of recombinant human dentin sialoprotein (rh-DSP) on the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), Akt (A), and nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) (B, C) pathways in human dental pulp cells (HDPCs). The expression of MAPK and NF-κB protein was measured by Western blot analysis. Cells were incubated with rh-DSP (10 ng/mL) for up to 120 min (A, B). After stimulation with rh-DSP for 60 min, cells were fixed and immunostained with anti-p65 antibody, and examined by confocal microscopy (C). NF-κB expression was localized mainly in the cytoplasm (b, green), while the nucleus was stained with FITC (a, red). A merged image is shown in c (orange). Data are representative of 3 independent experiments.

sec.p: To elucidate whether a BMP-dependent mechanism may be involved in the effect of rh-DSP on HDPCs, we examined the level of BMP-2 expression. The up- regulation of BMP-2 mRNA began 12 hrs after the administration of 10 ng/mL rh-DSP; maximum expression was observed after 24 hrs (Fig. 4A). To determine whether rh-DSP activated signaling molecules downstream of BMP, we examined the effect of rh-DSP on Smad phosphorylation. rh-DSP significantly enhanced the phosphorylation of Smad1/5/8 in HDPCs (Fig. 4B).

caption.p: Involvement of recombinant human dentin sialoprotein (rh-DSP) in the BMP pathway in human dental pulp cells (HDPCs). Effects of rh-DSP on BMP-2 mRNA expression (A) and Smad1/5/8 phosphorylation (B). Effect of BMP-2 inhibitor (noggin) on rh-DSP-induced activation of Smad1/5/8, MAPK, Akt, and NF-κB (C). BMP-2 mRNA expression and activation of signal transduction pathways were determined by RT-PCR and Western blot analysis, respectively. Cells were cultured in osteogenic medium (OM) with or without DSP (10 ng/mL) for the times indicated (A, B). Cells were pre-treated with noggin (1 μg/mL) for 1 hr, then with rh-DSP (10 ng/mL) or rh-BMP-2 (10 ng/mL) for 60 min (C). Data are representative of 3 independent experiments.

sec.p: To confirm that rh-DSP operated through a BMP-dependent pathway, we treated HDPCs with a BMP inhibitor, noggin, for 1 hr, then co-incubated them with 10 ng/mL rh-DSP for a further 1 hr. The addition of 1 μM noggin, a BMP antagonist, inhibited rh-BMP-2- and rh-DSP-induced activation of Smad1/5/8, JNK, ERK, Akt, and NF-κB (Fig. 4C).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Primary HDPCs could be cultured only as far as passage 7, when replicative senescence occurred and proliferation stopped irreversibly. Our preliminary observation indicated that, despite use of the same method of cell isolation, some pulp samples did not yield cultures that showed rapidly growing cell clones or the formation of odontoblast-like characteristics. To overcome this problem, we used human immortalized cell lines of dental pulp.

In the present study, endogenous DSP gene expression was increased when rh-DSP was administered to HDPCs, suggesting the existence of autoregulation of DSP gene in HDPCs. In addition, a 10 ng/mL quantity of rh-DSP had a similar effect on the expression of DSP protein as compared with 20 ng/mL of rh-DSP for 14 days, suggesting that an autoregulatory negative feedback loop limits the activity of rh-DSP. MTT and migration assays in HDPCs showed that rh-DSP enhanced proliferation and chemotaxis in dose- and time-dependent manners. A 10 ng/mL quantity of rh-DSP had a similar effect on cell proliferation and migration as compared with 20 ng/mL of rh-DSP, suggesting that 10 ng/mL was the optimal concentration of rh-DSP on the HDPCs.

Our results demonstrated that rh-DSP significantly increased ALP activity levels and the induction of in vitro biomineralization, which exceeded the effects of ‘conventional’ osteogenic medium (OM) and rh-BMP-2. Furthermore, rh-DSP significantly increased the mRNA levels of the biomarkers examined (DMP-1, DSPP, ALP, OPN, and OCN) in a dose-dependent manner. Analysis of our in vitro data, collectively, indicates that rh-DSP stimulates HDPC differentiation and maturation. This finding is similar to those of previous reports, which have suggested that dentin matrix proteins induce the differentiation of embryonic ectomesenchymal cells (Deng et al., 2005), dental pulp stem cells (Liu et al., 2007), and DPCs (Nie et al., 2006) into odontoblast-like cells. Because a higher concentration of rh-DSP (20 ng/mL) did not stimulate maximal growth and odontoblastic differentiation compared with that achieved with 10 ng/mL rh-DSP, we cannot exclude the possibility that saturation of the DSP receptors limits this autocrine activation of cells. The intracellular DSP receptor signaling such as allosteric regulation or internalization of bound receptors therefore remains to be determined.

Other reports have suggested that other kinase pathways, such as p38, ERK, JNK, Akt, and NF-κB, may substitute for, activate, or modulate BMP signaling (Xiao et al., 2002). In this study, we found that JNK and ERK were activated by rh-DSP, becoming phosphorylated within 10 min of the onset of rh-DSP exposure and peaking after 30 min. However, previous studies showed that p38 MAPK activation plays an important role in osteoblastic differentiation (Greenblatt et al., 2010). Furthermore, the activation of JNK and ERK is necessary for the differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells and skeletal development (Tang et al., 2008). Recently, we reported that p38, ERK, and JNK were activated in HDPCs exposed to fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF-2) (Kim et al., 2010). These conflicting observations may result from differences in experimental procedure, cell type, or stimuli. Transcriptional regulation via Akt/NF-κB pathway activation involves a complex series of events. Activated Akt phosphorylates I-κB, causing its degradation (Baldwin, 1996). Our evidence suggesting increased Akt and NF-κB activation and nuclear translocation in rh-DSP-treated cells raises the possibility that the Akt/NF-κB pathway contributes to the growth and differentiation of HDPCs.

To determine the mechanism underlying the effect of rh-DSP on odontoblastic differentiation, we examined Bmp expression and BMP signaling. BMP signaling is initiated by receptor binding, propagated by the phosphorylation of the Smad1/5/8 complex, and finally translocated into the nucleus, resulting in the regulation of target gene transcription (Miyazono et al., 2005). Noggin is one of the osteoblast-secreted proteins that can limit BMP signaling through complexing with BMP, thereby preventing receptor binding (Wan et al., 2007). In this study, we found that rh-DSP enhanced the expression of BMP2 mRNA, and its downstream molecule Smad1/5/8 protein, suggesting that rh-DSP may influence HDPC functions through the BMP pathway. This finding was further supported by the fact that noggin inhibited rh-DSP-induced activation of Smad1/5/8, JNK, ERK, Akt, and NF-κB.

In summary, this is the first study to demonstrate the stimulation of HDPC growth, chemotaxis, and odontoblastic differentiation by rh-DSP through the coordinated BMP/JNK and ERK/MAP kinase/Akt/NF-κB signaling pathways. Since DSP was expressed not only in the odontoblasts of the primary dentin but also in the odontoblast-like cells of reparative dentin (Hwang et al., 2008), the function of DSP could be associated with synthesis and rate of dentin matrix formation and the conversion of predentin to mineralized dentin. Thus, rh-DSP has therapeutic potential for regenerative endodontics and apical periodontitis.

fn.p: This study was supported by a grant from the Korea Healthcare Technology R&D Project, Ministry for Health, Welfare & Family Affairs, Republic of Korea (A084458).
The author(s) declare no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
